WATER TREATMENT PLANT #1



EPA Facility ID #  100000121307





EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The City of Atlantic Beach Public Utilities Department operates  

The City of Atlantic Beach water Treatment Plant #1 located

at 469 11th Street, Atlantic Beach, Duval County Florida. 

This Plant is one of six water and Wastewater Plants operated 

by the City. Water Plant #1 and four other plants have quanties 

of regulated hazardous chemicals above the EPA threshold. The City

has a unified Risk Management Program which applies to each plant.

Only water Treatment Plant #1 operations and policies are presented 

in this Plan.



Water Treatment Plant #1 uses one regulated substances chlorine 

(CAS Number 7782-50-5)in the chlorination process.

The chlorination process consists of the use of chlorine from

one-ton cylinders to disinfect Drinking water.



In order to fulfill the requirements of the Risk Management Program

(RMP), the facility has developed an accidental

release prevention program and emergency action plan for the 

facility.The accidental release prevention program

satisfies the requirements for the USEPA RMP and the Occupational 

Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA)

Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The prevention program 

ensures that the facility is operated under safe

conditions and that any risk of an accidental release due to human 

error,the facility's prevention program ensures that

operating procedures are current and reviewed annually.Training also

plays a vital part in the facility's program.

Employees and contractors working near or on the chlorination process 

are required to be trained in the chlorination process and the hazards 

of chlorine.



To prevent equipment failure that could result in a release, the 

program ensures that equipment inspections, tests, and

preventive maintenance are performed in accordance with accepted 

engineering practices, manufacturer's recommendations, and 

planned main

tenance schedules.  All chlorine cylinders are examined 

upon delivery and are rejected if there are any signs of damage.

In addition, equipment pertaining to the chlorine process is visually

inspected daily.  The potential for a chlorine release is greatly 

reduced in the chlorination process due to the use

of a vacuum system from point of chlorine withdrawal to its point 

of application.  In the event that there is a failure

in chlorination equipment, the system will automatically shut down 

(i.e., failsafe).



All existing and proposed future chlorination equipment have been 

designed according to applicable standards and codes.

The facility maintains records and documentation on equipment 

inspection and tests. Precautions are taken to

ensure that new equipment and processes are inspected and testes,

that all changes on the process are authorized, and

employees are informed of changes.



The facility performed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) to address 

the hazards in the chlorination process and to

evaluate and control where potential for a chlorine release exists. 

Employees were involved in determining hazards of

the process and subsequent consequences. The chlorination process 

was found to be operating safely and no changes were recommended.



Active employee participation will ensure the success of the RMP at

the facility.  Employees have been assigned various

tasks to ensure that all elements of the RMP are implemented.  The 

facility has developed management forms to

assist employees in recording and documenting the various elements 

of the RMP.



At the time of the submittal of this Risk Management Program, there

have been no accidental releases of chlorine

at this facility in the past five years.  However, in the event that

there is an accidental release of chlorine, an

Emergency Action Plan has been written in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.38.

The facility is also included in the communityemergency response plan. 

Emplo

yees at the facility do not respond to 

accidental releases of chlorine, but coordinate

with outside responders.  Therefore, an Emergency Response Program is 

not required for the facility.  In the event that

a chlorine release occurs, all employees are required to evacuate the

process area and report the incident.  The

emergency action plan consists of evacuation procedures, facility 

emergency numbers, and coordination with the City

of Jacksonville Fire Department.  The plan also addresses notification

procedures to the public and the local emergency response agency.
